com.pb.sawdust.util.array

Class ArrayUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.util.array.ArrayUtil

  • public class ArrayUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    The ArrayUtil class provides a variety of static convenience methods for dealing with arrays.

      • getBaseComponentType

        public static java.lang.Class<?> getBaseComponentType(java.lang.Object array)
        Get the base component type for an array. The base component type of an array is the final type that the array holds: for one dimensional arrays, this is the same as its component type; for multidimensional arrays this is the type that the multidimensional holds. For example, the base component type of byte[][][] is byte (calling Class.getComponentType would return byte[][] as the componennt type).
        Parameters:
        array - The array in question.
        Returns:
        the base component type of array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array.

      • getDimensionCount

        public static int getDimensionCount(java.lang.Object array)
        Get the number of dimensions of an array. For example, a byte[][][] array has a dimension of 3. An array declared as X dimensional but composed of arrays will be seen to have X dimensions (e.g. an Object[] array filled with byte[][] arrays will have dimension 1, not 3).
        Parameters:
        array - The array in question.
        Returns:
        the number of dimensions of array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array.

      • getDimensions

        public static int[] getDimensions(java.lang.Object array)
        Get the dimensions of an array. The returned array has one entry for each dimension of the input array, and each entry indicates the length in the array of that dimension. This method is "naive" in the sense that it only uses the first element in each array dimension to determine dimension. That is, is assumes rectangularity and will return a "not strictly correct" result if the input array is jagged. If any dimension has a length of zero, then all subsequent dimensions are assumed to be of zero length (though an array may be declared as byte[2][0][3] such an array is effectively byte[2][0][0]). If an array has not been fully declared/filled (e.g. byte[4][5][] an exception will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        array - The array in question.
        Returns:
        an array describing the dimensionality of array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array, is null or has not been fully declared or filled.

      • isJagged

        public static boolean isJagged(java.lang.Object array)
        Determine whether an input array is jagged. An array is determined to be jagged if it is not rectangular; that is, if it composed of arrays of non-identical lengths. This method only checks up to the declared dimensions of a given array: if an array is declared as Object[][] but is filled with byte[][] arrays, it only determines whether the Object[][] array is jagged, not its component arrays.
        Parameters:
        array - The array in question.
        Returns:
        true if the array is jagged, false if it is rectangular.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array, is null or has not been fully declared or filled.

      • isOfDimension

        public static boolean isOfDimension(java.lang.Object array,
                    int[] expectedDimensions)
        Determine if an array has a given dimensionality. The dimensionality is defined by an array of integers whose length specifies the number of dimensions and whose elements specify the size of each dimension. For an array to have the specified dimensionality, it must be rectangular (isJagged(array) == false).
        Parameters:
        array - The array in question.
        expectedDimensions - The expected dimensionality of the input array.
        Returns:
        true if array has dimensionality expectedDimensions, false otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array.

        java.lang.ArrayStoreException - if value cannot be validly placed in array.

      • setValue

        public static <T> void setValue(java.lang.Object array,
                T value,
                int... index)
        Set the value of an array at the specified position. This method will work for both object and primitive arrays (the object value will be unboxed if the array holds primitives).
        Type Parameters:
        T - The object type of the value.
        Parameters:
        array - The array.
        value - The new value.
        index - The index position of the new value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array's length is not equal to index.length, or if array stores primitives but value cannot be unwrapped appropriately.
        java.lang.ArrayStoreException - if value cannot be set in array.

      • copyArray

        public static <T> T[] copyArray(T[] array)
        Copy an array. This method descends as deeply into the array and recursively copies any arrays that it finds. Though the copied arrays are newly instantiated, the components of the array are copied using System.arrayCopy(...), which means that only an object reference, not a newly allocated object, is copied. In other words, this method performs a "deep" copy with respect to arrays, but a "shallow" copy with respect to array components.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The component type of the input and output arrays.
        Parameters:
        array - The array to copy.
        Returns:
        a copy of array.

      • copyArray

        public static java.lang.Object copyArray(java.lang.Object array)
        Copy an array. This method descends as deeply into the array and recursively copies any arrays that it finds. Though the copied arrays are newly instantiated, the components of the array are copied using System.arrayCopy(...), which means that, in the case of objects, only an object reference, not a newly allocated object, is copied. In other words, this method performs a "deep" copy with respect to arrays, but a "shallow" copy with respect to array components.
        Parameters:
        array - The array to copy.
        Returns:
        a copy of array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array.

      • copyArray

        public static void copyArray(java.lang.Object srcArray,
             java.lang.Object destArray)
        Copy an array's contents to another array. This method descends into the source array and copies each element into the corresponding position in the destination array. Thus, in the case of multidimensional arrays, the array elements are copied, but not the composing sub-arrays. Thus, the source and destination arrays should be of the same shape; an exception will be thrown if the destination array is too small (or non-existent) in any of the source array's dimensions, but not if the destination array is too big.
        Parameters:
        srcArray - The source array.
        destArray - The destination array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayStoreException - if destArray is not an array in any dimension where srcArray is, or if the elements in srcArray cannot be held by destArray.
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if destArray's length in any dimension is smaller than srcArray.

      • buildArray

        public static <T> T[] buildArray(T[] inputArray,
                 int[] indices)
        Builds a new array from an input array and a list of indices. The order of the indices determines the order of the elements in the new array, and the indices may repeat. For example, the following code snippet: 
        
     String[] input = new String{"a","b","c"};
     int[] indices = new int[] {2,2,3,2};
     String output = buildArray(input,indices);
        will create output such that it looks like ["b","b","c","b"].
        Type Parameters:
        T - The component type of the input and output arrays.
        Parameters:
        inputArray - The array to build the new array from.
        indices - The indices of inputArray which specify the order and elements in the new array.
        Returns:
        a new array build from indices and inputArray.
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if indices contains any values less than 0 or greater than 1-inputArray.length.

      • buildArray

        public static <A> A buildArray(A inputArray,
               int[] indices)
        Builds a new array from an input array and a list of indices. The order of the indices determines the order of the elements in the new array, and the indices may repeat. For example, the following code snippet: 
        
     String[] input = new String{"a","b","c"};
     int[] indices = new int[] {2,2,3,2};
     String output = buildArray(input,indices);
        will create output such that it looks like ["b","b","c","b"].

        This method works with both primitive and object arrays, though for object arrays, buildArray(T[], int[]) will be slightly more efficient and generally more typesafe.

        Type Parameters:
        A - The array type of the input and output objects.
        Parameters:
        inputArray - The array to build the new array from.
        indices - The indices of inputArray which specify the order and elements in the new array.
        Returns:
        a new array build from indices and inputArray.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if inputArray is not an array.
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if indices contains any values less than 0 or greater than 1-inputArray.length.

      • getIterator

        public static <E> java.util.Iterator<E> getIterator(E[] array)
        Get an iterator over an object array. The iterator does not lock/synchronize on the input array, and should not be considered threadsafe.
        Type Parameters:
        E - The type of element returned by the iterator at each iteration.
        Parameters:
        array - The array to create the iterator for.
        Returns:
        an iterator over array.

      • getIterator

        public static java.util.Iterator getIterator(java.lang.Object array)
        Get an iterator over an array. What the iterator iterates over (primitives or objects) is determined internally. The iterator does not lock/synchronize on the input array, and should not be considered threadsafe.
        Parameters:
        array - The array to create the iterator for.
        Returns:
        an iterator over array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array.

      • getThreadSaferIterator

        public static java.util.Iterator getThreadSaferIterator(java.lang.Object array)
        Get an iterator which moderately "thread safer" than that returned by getIterator(Object). This method creates an iterator from a copy of the input array, which helps to decouple the calling application from this method. However, the copy of the array is performed using copyArray(Object), which means that the elements of the array are only "shallow" copied. Therefore, unless aceess to mutable array components (outside of arrays - since copyArray(Object) copies all arrays within an array) is controlled in such a way to make them threadsafe, this iterator cannot be considered fully threadsafe.
        Parameters:
        array - The array to create the iterator for.
        Returns:
        an iterator over a copy of array.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if array is not an array.

      • getThreadSaferIterator

        public static <E> java.util.Iterator<E> getThreadSaferIterator(E[] array)
        Get an iterator which moderately "thread safer" than that returned by getIterator(Object). This method creates an iterator from a copy of the input array, which helps to decouple the calling application from this method. However, the copy of the array is performed using copyArray(Object), which means that the elements of the array are only "shallow" copied. Therefore, unless aceess to mutable array components (outside of arrays - since copyArray(T[]) copies all arrays within an array) is controlled in such a way to make them threadsafe, this iterator cannot be considered fully threadsafe.
        Type Parameters:
        E - The type of element returned by the iterator at each iteration.
        Parameters:
        array - The array to create the iterator for.
        Returns:
        an iterator over a copy of array.

      • apply

        public static <X,Y,Z extends Y> Z[] apply(X[] values,
                          Function1<? super X,Y> function)
        Apply a function to each element in an array of inputs, returning an array of outputs. More precisely, the ith element of the output array is equal to function.apply(values[i]). The output array is dynamically generated based on the result of function.apply(Y), so the input values must have at least one value. The returned array will be of type Z extends Y, where Z is the least common class of all of the outputs, as defined by ClassInspector.getLowestCommonClass(Class, Class).
        Type Parameters:
        X - The supertype of the input of function.
        Y - The type of the output of function.
        Z - The component type of the returned array.
        Parameters:
        values - An array of values to apply the function to.
        function - The function the values will be appplied to.
        Returns:
        an array of outputs.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if values does not contain at least one value.

      • apply

        public static <X,Y> Y[] apply(X[] values,
              Function1<? super X,? extends Y> function,
              Y[] outputArray)
        Apply a function to each element in an array of inputs, returning an array of outputs. More precisely, the ith element of the output array is equal to function.apply(values[i]). The supplied output array will be used if values.length == outputArray.length, otherwise reflection will be used to dynamically create a correctly sized array.
        Type Parameters:
        X - The supertype of the input of function.
        Y - The type of the output of function and the component type of outputArray.
        Parameters:
        values - An array of values to apply the function to.
        function - The function the values will be appplied to.
        outputArray - A representative output array to put the outputs in.
        Returns:
        an array of outputs.
